ymp_slice.ymp_title: Comparing Q to K to determine shift

ymp_slice.ymp_txt: The previous module suggested a way to tell whether a system is at equilibrium and, if not at equilibrium, which direction the system will shift to reach chemical equilibrium.
Recall this diagram showing forward and reverse rates for the reaction between 2NO2's to form N2O4.
If Q = K, then we know the system is at chemical equilibrium.
But if Q is less than K, then Q will have to increase so that Q becomes equal to K at equilibrium.
For Q to increase, the reaction must shift in the forward direction. That is, the amount of products must increase and the amount of reactants must decrease.

The shift to the right arises when the forward reaction occurs at a faster rate than the reverse reaction. If products are produced more rapidly than reactants, the total concentration of products will increase and the total concentration of reactants will decrease.
Similarly if Q is greater than K, then Q will have to decrease such that Q=K at equilibrium.
For Q to decrease, the reaction must shift in the reverse direction. That is, the amount of reactants will increase and the amount of products will decrease.

When the reverse reaction occurs at a faster rate than the forward reaction, reactants are produced more rapidly than products. Thus the overall concentrations of reactants increase while the concentrations of products decrease.
